div.head: New Harmony 's First Utopians, 1814–1824
div.p: A steamboat carrying salt and store goods slowly made its way up the Wabash River on the morning of April 29, 1823. As the boat prepared to stop for firewood at the unique town of New Harmony on the Indiana frontier, the villagers were unusually excited. This was the first steamboat they had ever seen navigate the seventy miles from the Ohio River to New Harmony . George Rapp, their leader, and a few others boarded a small boat to view the welcome arrival. Rapp ordered the town cannon fired to mark the occasion. In carrying out his command, the townsmen overloaded the cannon and fired it with a crowd of spectators standing nearby. When the noise of the blast died away, a boy had lost his foot, a man had been knocked to the ground and nearly killed by a wound to the head, and five others had been injured.1

div.p: Rarely had such frenzy seized the community of the Harmony Society on the Wabash or such irresponsible behavior distracted its members from their methodical routine. These German immigrants were known for their solid achievements through discipline, sobriety, and hard work. Their town was a monument to planning, order, and cleanliness. The eight hundred residents were Lutheran dissenters who since 1803 had come to America from the German province of Württemberg. They had built the town of Harmony in Butler County, Pennsylvania , and had moved to the Indiana Territory in 1814 seeking land to accommodate new members, a navigable river for trade, and a mild climate for grape culture. In only nine years they had literally carved New Harmony out of the wilderness. Their estate of nearly twenty thousand acres had become a model of communal enterprise that attracted visitors from the United States and Europe. In turn, the visitors, especially those from England , had made New Harmony famous by describing it in letters, newspaper articles, and books that were read widely throughout America, the British Isles, and the German provinces.2

Looking ashore on that spring morning in 1823, the steamboat crew could appreciate many of the visitors' tales. Where else on the American frontier could so many people be found living in such material abundance, cultural refinement, and economic security? Long before reaching the town itself, the boatmen could see evidence of the two to three thousand acres that had been fenced and brought under cultivation. Large fields were planted with wheat, corn, oats, sugarcane, cotton, tobacco, flax, hemp, rye, and barley. Acre upon acre surrounding the village was green with vineyards and apple, peach, and pear orchards. Cattle, horses, and prized merino sheep grazed on the hillsides. New Harmony was a prosperous and almost completely self-sufficient, communally owned city of some 180 buildings. Factories, mills, and granaries combined with the produce of the fields and forests to provide the necessities of life. Through a post office, bank, store, and tavern, commerce was carried on. A school, library, church, and community house and public gardens fostered education, culture, and religion. Each family lived comfortably in a log, frame, or two-story brick house on a fenced lot with its own garden and cow. Single adults had rooms in one of four dormitories occupied by both sexes. No community had greater solidarity or a clearer vision of its Utopian future. Rapp's followers were convinced that they were a chosen people, divinely appointed to help establish the Kingdom of God on earth after the imminent Second Coming of Christ. As such, they had united in imitation of first-century Christian communism to found their Harmony Society in 1805.3

The religious foundation so little understood by contemporaries but so essential to the existence of New Harmony had been laid decades before in the German province of Württemberg. There, twenty-five miles northwest of Stuttgart in the picturesque village of Iptingen on the little Enz River, Johann Georg Rapp was born in 1757. And there, in the midst of growing religious and political tensions, he grew to manhood, having learned vine dressing from his father and having become a weaver by trade but feeling all the while an irresistable desire to preach. Disillusioned with the cold formality of the state Evangelical (Lutheran) church and attracted to the emotional appeal of pietism, he separated from the church in 1785. The magnetism of his personality and the potency of his ideas had already made him the leader of other religious dissenters who were meeting illegally in his house. The nucleus from which the Harmony Society would spring had formed.4

The apprehension of the Evangelical church fathers grew in proportion to the number of Rapp's followers. By 1791 the clergy convinced the civic authorities of Württemberg that by refusing to support the church or permit their children to attend

the Lutheran-controlled public schools, the separatists posed a threat to civil government. An unsuccessful attempt to silence Rapp and to crush his movement ensued. Rapp refused all suggestions that he stop preaching, asserting to the officials at Maulbronn, "I am a prophet and am called to be one." When he was imprisoned briefly, his popularity increased. Upwards of twenty thousand people eventually considered him their prophet.

Rapp's doctrines held a strong appeal for the common German people during a difficult time in their history. His ideas were straightforward, strong in emotional content, and most compelling once firmly believed. Basically, they emphasized the beliefs and practices of the early Christians as Rapp understood them. Heartfelt conversion from sin and daily, personal communion with God were his cardinal pietistic principles. Constant pursuit of Christian perfection prepared the righteous for the second appearance of Christ and the work of setting up the new social order that would accompany the Kingdom of God on earth. Biblical prophecy provided the most important element for cementing Rapp's followers as a group. It gave them the sense of being a select few with a divine mission. They increasingly saw themselves as the Chosen People of God described as the Church of Philadelphia and the Sunwoman in chapters 3 and 12 of the Book of Revelation. As the modern embodiment of the ancient Church of Brotherly Love, the Rappites considered themselves God's most faithful and favored congregation (Rev. 3:8–12). Later, they viewed their communal society in America as an example for all Christendom, its members reaching toward holiness, bearing up under every burden, and reaping the promises of eternal reward mentioned in St. John's vision.5

As Rapp's utterances became ever more unorthodox, the Württemberg government demanded that he submit a written statement of faith in 1798. From this time and this statement the Harmony Society can be said to have taken shape. The statement indicated that the Rappites opposed infant baptism, confirmation, oaths, and military service. Although they respected the place of government in human affairs, they upheld the right of like-minded people to form separate congregations and to establish schools to promote their doctrines. They also asserted that only the righteous should be permitted to take holy communion.6

div.p: Such open rebellion against religious and civil authority could not go uncensored in Lutheran Württemberg. Rapp was summoned to Maulbronn again for questioning in 1803 and commanded not to speak outside Iptingen. It was then that he decided that the time had come to seek a haven for himself and those faithful to his teachings beyond the reach of an established church. America beckoned prophetically, as it had to so many earlier Europeans, as the pristine land of millennial promise, and Rapp willingly yielded. Accompanied only by his son, John; Dr. John Christopher Mueller; and Dr. P. Friedrich Conrad Haller, who soon forsook him, Rapp arrived in Philadelphia on October 7, 1803. He had every expection of being joined by thousands of German separatists as soon as he could locate lands for their settlement. In reality, although many German pietists immigrated in the early nineteenth century and some founded their own communal societies as at Zoar, Ohio ; Ebenezer, New York ; and Amana, Iowa , not more than 1,200 became residents of one of Rapp's three towns.

Rapp and his advance party of 1803 visited and tried without success to secure federal government land on the Muskingum River in the new state of Ohio . Not realizing that a land grant or special price would take congressional action, the Harmonist visionary appealed to President Thomas Jefferson in a personal visit. Jefferson expressed interest in Rapp's project and his high ideals but explained that only Congress could grant such a favor. Later, in 1806, the United States House of Representatives rejected the Harmony Society's request for a grant of land on the Wabash near Vincennes .7 In the meantime, hundreds of separatists left Württemberg believing that they were fulfilling the prophecy of the Sunwoman of Revelation 12:6 who "fled into the wilderness, where she hath a place prepared of God" and began arriving in the United States in July, 1804. Their somewhat premature arrival forced Rapp to purchase a much less desirable site on the shallow Connoquenessing River twelve miles from the Ohio River in Butler County, Pennsylvania , north of Pittsburgh where the climate would not be favorable for vineyards.

There the Rappites adopted first-century Christian communism as much out of necessity as out of religious conviction. They had established a treasury of contributions for minor expenses in Württemberg that was administered by Frederick Reichert who became Rapp's adopted son at Harmony, Pennsylvania
7 Ibid., 83–90; U.S., Annals of Congress, 9 Cong., 1 Sess., 476–77; Wilson, Angel and the Serpent, 16–20.
But in America their financial situation was so critical that if the immigrants were to survive as a group complete economic sharing and central administration of available funds were essential. There could be no rich and poor, only brothers and sisters sharing a common purse as the early Christians had done. Like all other Christian communitarians before and since, the Rappites cited verses from the Acts of the Apostles as justification for their communism:
And all that believed were together, and had all things common; And sold their possessions and goods, and parted them to all men, as every man had need (Acts 2:44, 45). And the multitude of them that believed were of one heart and of one soul: neither said any of them that ought of the things which he possessed were his own; but they had all things common. … Neither was there any among them that lacked; for as many as were possessors of lands or houses sold them, and brought the prices of the things that were sold, And laid them down at the apostles' feet: and distribution was made unto every man according as he had need (Acts 4:32, 34, 35).

Rapp had become convinced of the feasibility of communal living partly by reading the 1741 German edition of Johann Valentin Andreae's Christianopolls. First printed in Latin in 1619, this novel by the well-known seventeenth-century Württemburg social reformer and clergyman described the workings of an imaginary communal Christian republic in great detail. Rapp applied the ideas of Andreae to his Harmony Society and eventually taught that God had intended all mankind to live communally. Adam's sin, he suggested, had substituted self-seeking and private property for the pure communism of God's plan. Only in the harmonious world created by the saints upon Christ's return would this perfect condition be universally revived. It was Rapp's intention that the communism of the Harmony Society be a beginning to this revolutionary process.8

On February 15, 1805, the Harmony Society became a corporate body at Harmony, Pennsylvania , when 450 to 500 charter members signed the Articles of Association which constituted their solemn agreement. Each one gave over all his property to the Society and pledged to submit to the rules, to promote the interests of the congregation, and to relinquish all claims to reimbursement should he withdraw. In return the Society promised each member complete access to its religious and educational benefits, all the necessities of life in sickness
8 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 56, 239–41, 313; Johann V. Andreae, Christianopolis: An Ideal State of the Seventeenth Century, trans. Felix E. Held ( New York , 1916).
and in health, and a cash donation if he should leave the group while in good standing. Eight hundred members were taken into the Harmony Society at Harmony. As late as 1818 at New Harmony , members still were being admitted in groups as large as fifty by merely signing the original Articles of Agreement after a six- to eight-week trial period. In 1818 the community decided to destroy the record telling what each person had donated to the Society and to repeal the section of the articles that guaranteed a parting cash gift. This enhanced the equality of all within the communistic brotherhood, cancelled any hopes the rising generation may have had of gaining family inheritances, and insured against the nagging problem of demands for exorbitant payment by departing members.9

By 1820 the population of New Harmony included Society members, candidates for membership, apprentices, German indentured servants who had come to America after 1816 partly on Rapp's encouragement but without sufficient funds for passage, and a few former slaves whose freedom the Society had purchased in return for a set time of indentured service. By 1821 Rapp was persuaded that many of the recent German immigrants who became members were ill prepared by commitment of faith or communal orientation to add to the stability and progress of the Society. Therefore, he decided to protect the community from any further mass inductions by forbidding members to write any more letters of enticement to German friends and by drawing up a new, more explicit, individual contract for future members. This contract included the basics of the 1805 Articles but had to be more formally signed by the new member and countersigned by "George Rapp and Society" in the presence of witnesses.10

The Harmonists experienced a religious revival in 1807 and 1808 at the time that the Second Great Awakening was popularizing camp meetings and shaking the foundations of American Calvinism and the Shakers were sending missionaries west to found communal societies in Ohio, Kentucky , and Indiana. Millennialism and perfectionism became hallmarks of subsequent Rappite thought and practice. Their expectation of Christ's immediate return and the establishment

During and after the 1807 revival Rapp increasingly devoted himself to the interpretation of Scripture and world events as they might apply to the coming millennium. He gave literal meaning to Jesus' words,
if I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again, and receive you unto myself; that where I am, there ye may be also (John 14:3). Hereafter shall ye see the Son of man sitting on the right hand of power, and coming in the clouds of heaven (Mark 14:62). Blessed are those servants, whom the Lord when he cometh shall find watching: verily I say unto you, that he shall gird himself, and make them to sit down to meat, and will come forth and serve them (Luke 12:37). Although it can be assumed that the Harmonist preacher knew Jesus' caution that "of that day and hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels of heaven, but my Father only" (Matt. 24:36), he felt strongly that the Napoleonic wars signalled mystically that Christ's return was close at hand. While at New Harmony he had an insatiable appetite for news. He closely observed the fate of Napoleon and Italy , comet sightings in Europe, the Congress of Vienna , the formation of the Holy Alliance, the fighting between France and Spain in 1823, and events in far-off China . He linked all of these developments to the millennial prophecies in Daniel and Revelation. The evening religious discussions at New Harmony often focused on the theme of Christ's second coming, with references made to biblical passages and to the writings of mystics Johannes Tauler, Jakob Boehme, and Emanuel Swedenborg and philosopher Johann Herder.12 Rapp finally concluded that virtually all Scripture pointed in this grand direction. On May 4, 1823, he confided to his diary:
When Christ announced His coming Kingdom of God and preached it, all nations which wished the improvement of their life and purity and heart had a part in it. Let us too hope that in our critical times fairness and brotherly love may commonly flourish among men, where the duties of those well disposed and the will of the Lord will be done in Earth as in Heaven, as is now already done in the Harmonie (i.e., the Harmony Society). This comforting message of peace the Bible proclaims in almost all chapters of the Old and New Testament. Our period of time is suited for this, all disagreements and revolutions are evolutions and purpose toward the high goal, so just have patience.13

div.p: At the insistence of Father Rapp the community later began to collect a "church fund" in specie that was intended to shield the Society against the monetary uncertainties preceding Christ's return. Along with freshly kept flour for bread making, this fund was to be available on a moment's notice for Rapp's historic pilgrimage to Jerusalem where he would introduce his righteous band to the triumphant Savior. Under the exclusive, even secret, control of the Harmonist patriarch, the church fund grew to a half million dollars in gold and silver coins in a vault under his bedroom in Economy.14

Religious belief, then, was the invisible framework that held the Harmony Society together and supported virtually every building and activity that could be observed in New Harmony between 1814 and 1824. But to outsiders unfamiliar with the subtle pietistic and millennial teachings of the charismatic Father Rapp, the importance of the Society and its frontier town rested on their rapid rise to economic and political prominence in the development of Indiana and the American West. Under the astute leadership of the elder Rapp and his adopted son, Frederick (Reichert) Rapp, the little German village quickly had become an oasis of trade on a frontier of thinly scattered English and French settlers. The absence of nearby competitive towns worked in favor of New Harmony 's well-managed economic growth. Except for Vincennes on the Wabash fifty miles overland to the north, Newburgh thirty-five miles to the southeast on the Ohio River, and Shawneetown eighty miles down the Wabash and Ohio in Illinois , there were few places in the entire region besides New Harmony to grind grain, sell pelts, or buy supplies.

George Rapp insisted that his people balance their economy among agriculture, manufacturing, and commerce. By 1819, midway through the decade they would live in Indiana, his Harmonists were providing for nearly all of their own needs and selling more than $12,000 worth of agricultural produce annually.15 The following year their manufactured goods were valued at $50,000, exceeding that of any Indiana county except Scott.16 The Rappite cotton and woolen mills were powered by

The New Harmony general store offered its pioneer shoppers a remarkable selection of goods produced in the Rappites' own fields and woodlands, mills and factories. A wide variety of fruits, vegetables, and grains were available together with the meat, hides, and leather of wild and domesticated animals. Feathers, quills, eggs, butter, cheese, wax, and tallow were in good supply. Manufactured wares came almost exclusively from the town's six grain, hemp, oil, and saw mills and the many workshops in which seventy-five Harmonist men, a dozen women, and thirty boys and girls worked in 1820.19 The store carried fine woolen, cotton, and linen cloth, thread, and rope. One could go there for leather shoes, gloves, boots, hats, and mittens or for saddles, bridles, harnesses, wagons, carts, and plows. Harmonists' orders were filled without charge, but their frontier neighbors paid prices high enough to arouse periodic complaints.20 An advertisement in the Vincennes
Western Sun in May, 1819, announced that "F. Rapp, Will always have on hand, and for sale, THE FIRST QUALITY OF STRONG BEER, by the Barrel, at Harmony, Indiana."21 By the barrel at the store and by the drink at the tavern, the Harmonists attracted a brisk business not only in beer and whiskey, which they produced almost exclusively for sale, but also in wine, which they themselves enjoyed. Drunkenness, however, was not tolerated within the Society or among the tavern patrons who sometimes took offense at the strict Rappite enforcement of temperance.22

Frederick Rapp held the national government responsible for not enacting protective tariffs. He reported that manufacturing in New Harmony was hurt so severely by the depression that its workshops stood almost completely idle by 1821.23

Nevertheless, the Utopian German colony remained economically sound during the national crisis because of its solid agricultural base. Harmonist commerce, although reduced, also continued because of its wide acceptance before the depression. Branch stores had been set up at the nearby towns of Vincennes , Indiana, and Albion and Shawneetown, Illinois . At the more distant trading centers of Corydon, Indiana; Louisville; Pittsburgh; St. Louis ; and New Orleans , trusted agents handled Rappite business.24 The Golden Rose trademark placed on Harmonist manufactures had become, in fact, a familiar and respected symbol across the United States and into Canada , Mexico, Cuba, England, Scotland , the Netherlands,
France, Switzerland , and Germany .25 Few who used Harmonist products realized the religious significance of the trademark. To most it merely meant that the high quality of the goods inside could be taken for granted. To Rapp's followers it stood for God's future kingdom on earth referred to as a golden rose in Martin Luther's translation of Micah 4:8.26 Of all their products the Harmonists took greatest pride in their fine cloth, especially their flannel, which was said by the English settlers in Albion, Illinois , to be superior even to the best they had brought from Wales .27

Commerce led Rapp's community into banking. The Farmers Bank of Harmony was one of the first in Indiana. Free from the corruption and political involvements that plagued many other private, "wildcat" banks and crippled the state-chartered

bank at Vincennes , the Rappite institution fared better than most. Frederick Rapp served as its president and personally signed all notes along with cashier John L. Baker, who had Anglicized his name from Langenbacher for business purposes. In 1817 Frederick and five non-Harmonists were authorized by the Indiana legislature to establish branches of the Vincennes bank in Posey and Gibson counties, but these never materialized. When the Vincennes bank was reorganized in 1821 in an attempt to save it from the fraud and near bankruptcy into which it had fallen, Frederick was named to the new board of directors. However, he and the others found this bank beyond redemption from the entanglement of its own mismanagement, and it was closed by court order the following year.28

Failing banks, unstable currency, and severe depression helped convince the Rappite leaders that the West was a poor center for business operations. But these same tenuous circumstances made other frontiersmen notice the exceptional economic strength of communal New Harmony . This resulted in occasional requests for loans from the Harmony Society, most of which were refused. When Indiana's first governor, Jonathan Jennings, asked for $1,000 at 10 percent interest for his personal use, he was turned down. When the Indiana state treasurer asked the Rappites for $5,000 to shore up the state itself in 1823, however, the German communalists acknowledged their obligation to keep the state government solvent by granting the funds at the standard 6 percent interest. New Harmony was the only community in Indiana in a position to give such financial assistance.29

Communally organized labor was one secret of New Harmony 's economic success. Advantages of this arrangement included full employment, occasional rotation of jobs to avoid boredom, and the making of every task a friendly, cooperative endeavor. The Rappite men possessed skills in every trade needed to build and operate a nineteenth-century town. They were organized into companies under master tradesmen. The men of the building trades, sawyers, stonecutters, masons, bricklayers, and carpenters, carried out the assignments of their foremen as their contribution to the common cause. The

weavers, spinners, shoemakers, tailors, blacksmiths, and coopers did the same, as did the farmers, millers, meatcutters, wagonmakers, brewers, and distillers. The master tradesmen directed the work and taught apprentices. When members needed hats, coats, or other personal items, they applied to the foreman of their trade and received an order signed by George Rapp which was honored at the store. When nonmembers were served by the blacksmith or shoemaker, they paid the foreman and received a receipt from Rapp himself. Thus, common labor and common funds were strictly controlled and under the jealous personal supervision of Father Rapp.30

Although all able-bodied Harmonists worked, no one was intentionally overworked. Many hands and a regulated schedule made daily labor as light as possible. The sound of French horns awakened the communitarians each workday morning, but members made no claim to living a rigorous monastic life of self-denial.31 Their appearance was much like that of present-day Amish or Hutterites. Rappite men had long hair and dressed in plain blue or brown frock coats or surtouts, trousers, and shoes. Rappite women wore white caps, checkered neckerchiefs, cloth gowns, and checked aprons.32 The cessation of sexual relations that the group had agreed to in Pennsylvania during the 1807 religious revival might have seemed ascetic to visitors, but families remained together, a few children continued to be born, and Father Rapp reluctantly performed several marriages at New Harmony in 1817.33 More important from an economic standpoint, many women whose time would have been consumed by the duties of motherhood were freed to weave, garden, and labor in the fields and factories.

If the Harmonists seemed serious, even somber, at their work, it was due as much to their native background as to any religious factor. "Build, build, build and die" is a slogan still used in Germany today to suggest the work-oriented nature of the people of Swabia from which the followers of George Rapp emigrated. Yet, these Swabian Germans also had a native love of music that turned working groups into singing groups. tunes to be performed for visitors and for Society gatherings.34 Children under fifteen, when not in school, were employed in light chores such as planting corn and pumpkins or crushing oil from peach kernels. Teenaged youth were apprenticed in one of the trades. Harvest time was the grand communal occasion. Hundreds of Rappite men, women, and children marched to the fields led by their own band, which often played for the field hands at other times and was probably the first town band in Indiana. Inspired by the music and fellowship, the Rappites were reported to harvest a hundred acres in a single day.35 This congenial situation induced Father Rapp to observe that his divinely inspired community was a place
where those who occupy its peaceful dwellings, are so closely united by the endearing ties of friendship, confidence and love, that one heart beats in all, and their common industry provides for all. Here, the members kindly assist each other, in difficulty & danger, and share with each other, the enjoyments, and the misfortunes of life; one lives in the breast of another, and forgets himself; all their undertakings are influenced by a social spirit, glowing with noble energy, and generous feeling, and pressing forward to the haven of their mutual prosperity.36

The smooth operation of the social and economic enterprises at New Harmony was due largely to the effort of John Christopher Mueller, John Baker, and Frederick Eckensperger. Mueller had accompanied George Rapp to America in 1803 and had donated his medical skills to the care of Society members. His knowledge of the medical qualities of herbs became so well known that other experts such as Constantine Rafinesque came to Indiana to discuss his work and to observe the botanical garden behind his house on Main Street. Mueller also contributed to the community by directing the band, composing music, teaching school, and operating the Harmonist printing press after its acquisition in 1824.37 Baker led the advance party that

Rappite women serenaded Robert Owen and his son William during their visit to the New Harmony cotton mill in 1824 when a rainstorm temporarily interrupted the work schedule. See Joel W. New Harmony Movement, 22.

sought out and purchased the original land for New Harmony in 1814. Acting on Father Rapp's instructions, he bought sufficient territory along the Wabash River in Indiana and Illinois to seal the Harmonists off from intruding neighbors and to insure their exclusive control of a several-mile stretch of the river. Baker survived the malaria epidemic that filled scores of unmarked graves in the New Harmony cemetery during the first year of settlement to become the town's storekeeper and bank cashier. In 1821 he and John Reichert were sent as emissaries to collect old debts and inheritances due the Harmonists in their native Württemberg. As a result of this mission, the Württemberg government established a consulate in the United States .38 Eckensperger was well known to visitors as the keeper of New Harmony 's tavern, which also served as the inn. Within the Society he was loved as a schoolteacher and composer of keyboard and vocal music.39

Ultimate guidance of New Harmony 's development was in the trusted hands of George and Frederick Rapp. With the charisma of a modern-day guru, George had been the unquestioned spiritual leader of the Harmonists since their formation as a separatist group in Württemberg during the last quarter of the eighteenth century. He was the patriarch and prophet of his people. With a full beard and a strong, sympathetic voice and piercing blue eyes he was said to have communicated his ideas in carefully thought-out sentences punctuated by appropriate gestures. After 1809 his disciples reverently called him "Father."40

Rapp's religious mysticism, however, was balanced by a keen insight into practical matters. By vote of the men and women at Harmony, Pennsylvania , he held the office of president of the Harmony Society from its creation in 1805.41 Tall for a Swabian at nearly six feet and a vigorous man of fifty-six when he arrived in New Harmony in 1814, President Rapp possessed a broad knowledge of agriculture, mechanics, and administration. He took pride in a meticulous direction of daily affairs, which fact helps account for New Harmony 's economic and social stability. He and Frederick often could be found in

39 Arndt, Documentary History, I, 39, 40, 89, 94, 143; Wetzel, Frontier Musicians, 21, 32, 145.
40 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 340–41, 492. In 1824 Donald MacDonald found George Rapp "a stout healthy active old man of 67. He has a steady determined manner, but very little of that amiable mildness, which a patriarchal life and benevolent principles might be expected to produce." Diaries of Donald MacDonald, 230.
41 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 220.
the fields or factories inspecting operations, demonstrating methods, or simply enjoying working beside their friends.

The elder Rapp knew how to construct buildings, develop waterpower sites, and recognize soil types. From the portable greenhouse behind his New Harmony mansion to the huge brick church, called the Community House, built according to his design in the form of a Greek cross in 1822, he stamped his influence upon the architecture of the town. He directed the drainage of the mosquito-infested lowlands around New Harmony that had caused the dread malaria epidemics of 1814 and 1815. But, unlike Frederick, George was forced to deal with most Americans through an interpreter because he spoke very little English. Therefore, in 1805, when he adopted his faithful aide, he also made him business manager for the Society. Frederick then created the efficient system by which the community's activities were divided into seven departments, each with a manager appointed by Frederick and directly accountable to him.42

Frederick Rapp proved himself an invaluable agent for the Society. From St. Louis to Philadelphia and from Pittsburgh to New Orleans , he ably handled economic and legal business for his associates without evidence of ever having taken personal advantage of their confidence or betraying their vital interests. Frederick was a striking person: "a tall, rawboned, sallow complexioned, serious and plain German" wearing "a small crowned hat with a large brim over long brown hair, and a loose grey surtout" as one observer saw him in 1824.43 His interest in design, drafting, and town planning made New Harmony one of the earliest pre-planned towns in America. Influenced by the modern rectilinear design used in several Württemberg cities, in scores of Pennsylvania towns, including Philadelphia , and in the mythical communitarian Christian republic described by Andreae in Christianopolis, Frederick drew the plan upon which New Harmony was laid out by surveyors from Vincennes on August 8, 1814.44 Ten wide streets intersecting at right angles about a town square and rectangular lots of uniform size gave the place a distinct regularity

43 Quotations from Diaries of Donald MacDonald, 247; See also Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 252, 554.
44 Paul H. Douglas, "The Material Culture of the Harmony Society,"
Pennsylvania Folklore, XXIV (Spring, 1975), 6; Arndt, Documentary History, I, 26, 71.
with the most efficient use of space.45 It was largely at Frederick's insistence that tables and benches were put in the orchards for relaxation and meditation and that vases of flowers were placed on machines in the factories to beautify the work areas. The elder Rapp's fondness for flowers and shrubs also was evident in the life of the community. Near the south edge of town he had a hedge labyrinth planted so that men, women, and children picking their way along its maze-like paths to the tiny circular building in the center would be reminded of the difficulty of finding the meaning of life.46

The political voice of the eight hundred German communalists was expressed mostly through Frederick Rapp during the formative years of the state of Indiana. Fear that the Harmonists would dominate local politics by voting their own interests with the unity that marked their religious and economic commitments prevailed among the other citizens of Posey and Gibson counties. For this reason Baker apparently was denied his rightful seat from Posey County , and Frederick was the only Rappite permitted as one of four delegates from Gibson County to the historic Indiana Constitutional Convention of 1816.47 At Corydon, Frederick voted against the resolution to prepare a constitution and apply for statehood. But once the resolution passed, he worked vigorously to make the proposed fundamental law reflect the ideals of his constituency. While Frederick served on the committees that dealt with the executive branch of government and the militia, his father assured him by letter that "the invisible power of the Lord will not desert you in your effectiveness of reasoning wisely, also you have your good protective angels who support your politics which allows your sensitive premonition to sense things in advance so that you can act in a way pleasing to God and to reason, so that the enemies of the righteous will not prevail after they have disgraced themselves through their own lack of reason."48

In the committee on the militia Frederick Rapp represented the well-known pacifist position of the Harmonists. He succeeded in having Article VII of the Indiana Constitution provide that conscientious objectors could pay a fine in lieu of

46 Ross Lockridge, The Labyrinth ([ New Harmony , Ind.], 1941).
47 Arndt, Documentary History, I, 217; Arndt, Indiana Decade of George Rapp's Harmony Society, 17, 18.
48 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 165–70; Arndt, Documentary History, I, 226; John B. Dillon, A History of Indiana from Its Earliest Exploration by Europeans to the Close of Territorial Government in 1816 (reprint, New York , 1971), 557–58.
bearing arms.49 He also supported the strong statements against slavery that were written into Indiana's first Constitution. Later, in 1820, the Indiana legislature selected the noted Harmonist for the commission that chose the site for the permanent capital at Indianapolis . Although Frederick did not serve on a second commission that officially planned and laid out the new town, he drew an early map of Indianapolis that projected its development along the lines of Washington , D.C., and that may have influenced the final design of the state capital.50

If the outside world looked upon George Rapp's New Harmony as an inexplicable beehive of building, producing, and selling, the Harmonists within saw it as a God-given sanctuary in which to pursue Christian perfection and a well-rounded life while awaiting the climax of human history in Christ's second advent. Conveniently removed from the political and economic struggles beyond their community, the great majority of Rappites enjoyed the tranquil security of an ethnically homogeneous communal society. Isolated from other frontiersmen by language, culture, and religion, they went about their daily routine in a world apart. Beyond their assigned labor they found opportunities for personal enrichment and expression. All were encouraged to read, write, sing, and participate in religious services and discussions. By 1825 the New Harmony library, composed of some 360 books either donated by Society members or purchased, some in multiple copies, was one of the most extensive in the West. Its holdings included literature, philosophy, science, and medicine as well as theology.51

George Rapp's disciples were prodigious writers and copyists. Either as individuals or as designated "companies" they produced hundreds of handwritten books that they often embellished with ink and watercolor drawings. These leather-bound volumes were among the most personal Harmonist possessions, and many can still be seen in the archives of Old Economy Village in Ambridge, Pennsylvania . The books contain both original prose and poetry and works such as the hymns of the communitarian Baptists of the Ephrata Cloister

in Pennsylvania and the verse of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe and Friedrich von Schiller whom the Rappites admired. In 1820 the Harmony Society decided to have its favorite hymns published as the Harmonisches Gesangbuch, Theils Von andern Authoren, Theils neu Verfasst (Harmony Songbook Written by Early and Modern Authors).52

After purchasing their own press in 1824, the Harmonists printed Eine kleine Sammlung Harmonischer Lieder als die erste Probe der anfangenden Druckerey anzusehen (A Small Collection of Harmonist Hymns Presented as a First Sample of Their Printing). While at New Harmony , Rapp divided the entire congregation into five categories according to age and sex for the purpose of prose and poetry competition. From this effort 361 verses and short essays were judged worthy of publication. The result was the most intimate available picture of individual Rappite's feelings about religion, virtue, devotion, selflessness, and daily life and labor. It appeared in 1826 as Feurige Kohlen der aufsteigenden Liebesflammen im Lustspiel der Weisheit (Fiery Coals of the Ascending Flames of Love in the Joy of Wisdom).53

The most important book to come from the Rappite press at New Harmony was the only one ever written by George Rapp and the first on philosophy printed in Indiana. The Rappite leader titled it Gedanken über die Bestimung des Menschen, besonders in Hinsicht der gegenwärtigen Zeit and had it translated immediately into English as Thoughts on the Destiny of Man, Particularly with Reference to the Present Times. Both versions appeared within months of each other in 1824 and 1825. This book contained the core of Rapp's religious and social theories. In it he identified "Harmonie" as the essence of God's earthly kingdom that could only be attained by an unreserved pursuit of Christian perfection. In order to give his ideas the broadest credibility, the Harmonist preacher made every effort to have his "Harmonie" correspond to the description of the ideal "Humanitat" to which, according to the systematic arguments and popular books of the contemporary German philosopher and theologian Johann Herder, all human history was inevitably evolving. To make sure that there would be no discrepencies between the two Utopias, Rapp copied some sections of Herder's works into his own book verbatim. Then, unfortunately,

53 Feurige Kohlen der aufsteigenden Leibesflammen im Lustspiel der Weisheit (Oekonomie [Economy], Pa., 1826).
he concluded that his volume needed such extensive revision that the English version should not be circulated.54 As a consequence, Americans were denied one of their best opportunities to understand the underlying motivations of the Harmony Society on the Wabash .

A comprehensive and progressive educational system was at the heart of the cultural life of Father Rapp's New Harmony . Its academic, vocational, and adult programs were designed to meet the peculiar moral and practical, yet Utopian, needs of his ongoing religious commune.55 The system was modeled after the educational ideas of Luther and Andreae. Rapp and his followers had attended the vernacular free schools of Württemberg that were set up on Luther's plan in the sixteenth century. These schools stressed the teaching of reading, writing, religion, arithmetic, and music to produce a literate, Bible-reading citizenry for the benefit of church and state.56 The pedagogical methods employed in Andreae's idyllic Christianopolis appealed to the Rappite leader because of their communal and Utopian implications. Andreae gave top priority to the schooling of the youth of Christianopolis. He called for a meticulous selection of teachers, free coeducational state schools for children from ages six to fourteen, a wide-ranging curriculum, instruction in useful trades, and the use of laboratories, libraries, museums, and presses as teaching devices.57

George Rapp and his associates were sincerely committed to universal education, and their system in New Harmony met the high standards of Luther and Andreae in most respects. The Society's Articles of Association of 1805 guaranteed each Rappite "all such instructions in church and school as may be reasonably required, both for their temporal good and for their eternal felicity."58 In 1815, soon after arriving at New Harmony , Rapp observed that "men of learning and good moral character are very desirable in this country, that the old natives

quote.p: That kind of learning, and those fashionable accomplishments, which are useless and only calculated for show, should be entirely abolished, and in their stead, those true principles and habits of life should be established and confirmed, which most strongly tend to unite the hearts, minds & fortunes of the rising generation, & arouse their sleeping faculties, for the performance of all that is truly good and great. It is ardently hoped and believed that this sublime, predestinated system of Brotherly Union & Social Harmony, will ere long be universally established, for the restoration of the golden age, the dignity of the human character, and the happiness of man.60

div.p: The Harmonist parochial school on Tavern Street anticipated free tax-supported public schools in Indiana and most of the rest of the nation by nearly half a century. Frederick Rapp reported in 1819 that between eighty and one hundred children aged six to twelve were enrolled in classes held six days a week from 8:00 a.m. until noon.61 A Mr. Courtney, an English visitor in the same year, noted that "their school appears to be well conducted by a very respectable tutor who has a large number of scholars of different ages and of both sexes; all clean, neat and orderly. …"62 Orphans, young indentured servants who had the option to join the Society later, and children assigned by the courts as wards of the Harmonists attended this school along with the offspring of members.63

True to the Lutheran tradition, the Harmonist school emphasized the Bible, catechism, and instrumental and vocal music. But the curriculum was much broader than that. Students were taught reading, writing, arithmetic, spelling, geography, history, natural history, drawing, and Latin, German, English, and French grammar. In order to encourage the speaking of both English and German, classes were conducted in the former Monday through Wednesday and in the latter the remaining three school days.64 Textbooks in addition to the Lutheran Bible included the New England Primer, Pilgrim's Progress, Lindley Murray's English Grammar, Oliver
59 Quoted in Bole, Harmony Society, 77.
60 Rapp, Thoughts on the Destiny of Man, 95, 96.
61 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 210; Arndt, Documentary History, I, 775.
62 Arndt, Documentary History, I, 800.
63 Miller, "Education in the Harmony Society," 140–47.
64 Christiana F. Knoedler, The Harmony Society: A Nineteenth Century American Utopia ( New York , 1954), 97.
Goldsmith's geography, Noah Webster's spellers, ancient and modern histories, music books, and biographies of George Washington and other famous men. The university-trained Mueller and innkeeper Eckensperger were the principal teachers. They taught mostly by rote memorization and recitation. But writing exercises in blank books and on slates and spelling bees, study periods, physical exercises, craft lessons, and choral performances were also part of the instructional program. After 1817 Mueller started collecting items for a Christianopolis-like museum that has been preserved in the Feast Hall at Economy. Mueller and Eckensperger encouraged excellence by selecting the best exercises each week for display before the entire congregation at the Sunday morning service.65

The accomplishments of a few students demonstrate the effectiveness of the daily school in going beyond religious indoctrination and the "three Rs" to stimulate individual and cultural interests. Wallrath Weingartner joined the Society with his parents in 1805 at age ten, attended the school at Harmony, Pennsylvania , and became the most outstanding artist among the Rappites. With the other students he learned to sketch flowers and birds in two dimensions with ink outline and wash colors, which was the only Harmonist medium.66 Although no Rappite was permitted to make art more than an avocation, Weingartner did many paintings of single subjects and completed a full-color sketchbook in 1829 entitled "Ornithology or the Natural History of the Birds of the United States ." In this unpublished work he portrayed sixty-seven birds from Alexander Wilson's pioneering effort, American Ornithology (1808–1814), which was in the Harmony Society library. Weingartner's masterpiece proved him not only a flawless copyist but also an artist with keen sensitivity for selecting the finest available subjects and arranging them to achieve the best effect.67

Gertrude Rapp and Romelius L. Baker were also notable products of Harmonist education. Since Gertrude was Father Rapp's single grandchild by his only natural son, John, who was killed in a mill accident at Harmony, Pennsylvania , in

66 Daniel B Reibel, "Graphic Arts of the Harmony Society,"
Pennsylvania Heritage, III (March, 1977), 20.
67 Donald E. Pitzer, "Harmonist Folk Art Discovered," Historic Preservation, XXIX (October-December, 1977), 11, 12; "Letters," Historic Preservation, XXX (April-June, 1978), 47; Alexander Wilson, American Bird Engravings: All 103 Plates from American Ornithology ( New York , 1975).
1812, she was the darling of the community and not to be taken as a typical Rappite girl. Nonetheless, it is apparent that her school experiences prepared her to engage in a broad range of activities. She sang soprano in a girls' quartet; played the pianoforte in the orchestra; and, together with Rapp's daughter, Rosina, studied English at the Shaker West Union settlement near Vincennes in 1816. Gertrude also made paintings of her pet elk and other wildlife and directed the silk production at Economy.68 Romelius Baker, John's brother, showed such promise in economics that Father Rapp chose him to assist Frederick at New Harmony and to learn "Welt Weiszheit" (worldly wisdom). Romelius was elected a trustee to manage the Society's business affairs when Frederick died suddenly in 1834. Although his growing authority and prestige inside and outside the community eventually aroused the jealousy of the aging George Rapp, it was Romelius who succeeded the venerable leader as president of the Society when Rapp died in 1847. Baker gave responsible direction to the declining numbers of Rappites until his own death in 1868.69

The vocational program that followed completion of formal school at age fourteen gave each young person the training to fill a productive place in the communal economy. Each teenager was apprenticed to a skilled tradesman within the Society. The young men could choose any of the large variety of trades represented by the Harmonist craftsmen, but the young women were restricted to sewing, weaving, and spinning as advised in Christianopolis. 70

Adult education and relaxation took the forms of reading, writing, studying language and arithmetic, meeting for religious instruction and discussion, and, especially, gardening and music. Music lessons had been available to everyone in the Harmony Society from the beginning, but it was at New Harmony that music first became an important part of the educational program. Mueller and Eckensperger gave students music books with exercises that they had copied or composed themselves. Music lessons progressed from the study of scale degree names to writing and singing in two, three, and four parts. The

69 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, passim; Arndt, Documentary History, I, 143, 208, 663–65, II, passim; Arndt, George Rapp's Successors and Material Heirs, passim.
70 Miller, "Education in the Harmony Society," 79, 85; Andreae, Christianopolis, 260.
Harmonists' love of choral music resulted in fine congregational singing, small group performances, and the copying and composition of hymns that culminated in the publication of A Small Collection of Harmonist Songs in 1824. Three of the Society's favorite songs were "Durch Zerfallne Kirchen Fenster" ("Through Fallen Church Windows"), "Es Blüht ein Blümlein" ("There Blooms a Flower"), and "Herr, Führe Mich " ("Lord Lead Me") by Mueller. The six annual festivals of the Society were the most important occasions for singing the anthem-like compositions called "odes." In addition to the traditional Christmas, Easter, and Pentecost observances, festival days included Harmoniefest on February 15, to commemorate the date in 1805 when the Articles of Association were signed; Erntefest (Harvest Festival) in early August; and Liebesmahl (Love Feast), which was the Rappite observation of the Lord's Supper late in October.71

Instrumental music was taught from well-known method books by C.P.E. Bach, Leopold Mozart, August E. Mueller, and Frederick Kauer. The New Harmony band played at church services and on Saturday evenings from the tower balcony of the brick church. The band also entertained at the Fourth of July feasts at which the arrival of the first boatload of Harmonists at Baltimore on July 4, 1804, was remembered and at which nearby Indiana neighbors were sometimes honored guests. In 1817 the Society purchased a piano and was considering the installation of a pipe organ in the newly built brick church just before the decision to move back to Pennsylvania in 1824. More than a dozen Harmonists young and old played in the New Harmony orchestra that gained recognition in Niles Weekly Register and the Indianapolis
Indiana Gazette after a concert for their Indiana neighbors in October, 1822.72

The cultural, religious, and organizational dimensions of Harmonist life embodied a forward-looking conception of the rights of women. Rappite women enjoyed opportunities and privileges well beyond most of their early nineteenth-century sisters. As partners in New Harmony 's communistic organization, they had the same property rights as their husbands. Although no Rappite women held an office in the Harmony Society (as did eldresses in the Shaker hierarchy), they did vote
71 Wetzel, Frontier Musicians, 23, 24, 30, 150–52; Arndt, Documentary History, II, 552, 564.
72 Wetzel, Frontier Musicians, 23, 25–29; Arndt, Documentary History, I, 244, 258, 292, 302, 310, 311, 515, II, 454, 569, 639; Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 113, 246, 264, 348; Donald E. Pitzer and Josephine M. Elliott,
New Harmony 's Fourth of July Tradition ( New Harmony , Ind., 1976), 5.
in elections to determine which men would serve. Whether single females or mates in celibate marriages, they had control over their own bodies. They had the same right as men to leave their spouses or the Society itself, although no instances of such were recorded while at New Harmony .73 Even though Harmonist women were expected to perform the customary household tasks, they could be found in their long dresses, aprons, and bonnets sewing, weaving, and spinning in the workshops, cultivating in the gardens, and harvesting grain in the fields. Unlike most women in the United States at that time, they were assured of schooling and vocational training for their children of both sexes and lifelong learning opportunities for themselves. Books, newspapers, instrumental and choral music instruction and performances, religious services, discussion sessions, and evening classes in English and arithmetic were available for their intellectual and social stimulation.74

Harmonist women had entered as freely as their husbands into the consensus on celibacy during the religious fervor of the religious revival in 1807. At the urging of their patriarchal leader they had come to believe that sexual activity had no more place than private property in Christ's coming kingdom. Christine Rapp, George's wife, had set the example by agreeing with her husband to suspend sexual relations before they emigrated from Germany .75

Justification for the departure from customary marital relations was drawn from the writings of seventeenth-century German mystic Jakob Boehme, from Father Rapp's own concept of universal harmony, and from selected biblical passages. From Boehme came the idea that man, created in God's image, had had no physical sex organs before he sinned in the Garden of Eden and that he would be restored to that pure, God-like condition after Christ's return. The Harmonists' self-imposed celibacy was, therefore, an imitation of that perfect state that very soon was to be a reality once again. Father Rapp stressed chastity as an important step toward the universal harmony that had been lost in Adam's fall, which had not only separated human beings into male and female but had also effected their alienation from the Creator. The sacred task of the Harmony Society, as Rapp intended its name to imply, was the restoration of this lost cosmic harmony in anticipation of the millennium.
73 Of the thirteen members reported to have left the Society while at New Harmony , all were men probably seeking wives or their fortunes. See Bole, Harmony Society, 10.
74 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 332–33, 555.
75 Ibid., 98.
Celibacy was thus an element in the process of spiritual purification.76 Biblical passages that had led other communal groups to abandon sex helped convince the Harmonists also. Jesus, who himself never married, proclaimed that "there be eunuchs, which have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven's sake" (Matt. 19:12). St. Paul recommended that because of the nearness of Christ's second advent it was better to remain unmarried (I Cor. 7:27). The Book of Revelation (14:14) indicated that the 144,000 saints redeemed from the earth "are they which were not defiled with women; for they are virgins."

Outsiders often misunderstood the reasons for Harmonist celibacy and overemphasized it as the central concern of Rappite life. Lord Byron in Canto XV of Don Juan tried to tie Rappite sexual restraint to a Malthusian desire to limit population growth.

quote.p: When Rapp the Harmonist embargo'd marriage
In his harmonious settlement—(which flourishes
Strangely enough as yet without miscarriage,
Because it breeds no more mouths than it nourishes,
Without those sad expenses which disparage
What Nature naturally most encourages)—
Why call'd he "Harmony" a state sans wedlock?
Now here I have got the preacher at a dead lock.
Because he either meant to sneer at Harmony
Or marriage, by divorcing them thus oddly.
But whether reverend Rapp learn'd this in Germany
Or no, 'tis said his sect is rich and godly,
Pious and pure, beyond what I can term any
Of ours, although they propagate more broadly.
My objection's to his title, not his ritual,
Although I wonder how it grew habitual.
But Rapp is the reverse of zealous matrons,
Who favour, malgre Malthus, generation—
Professors of that genial art, and patrons
Of all the modest part of propagation;
Which after all at such a desperate rate runs,
That half its produce tends to emigration,
That sad result of passions and potatoes
Two weeds which pose our economic Catos.77

When the September, 1819, issue of the Harrisburg, Pennsylvania , Morgenröthe carried a report that sex in marriage and childbearing were forbidden in the Harmony Society and that no more than two children had been born in New Harmony , Frederick Rapp responded bluntly. It "is false and a lie
76 Ibid., 95–97.
77 George Gordon, Lord Byron, Don Juan ( New York , 1949), 465–66.
and an erroneous statement which has been spread among the public for the last 12 to 15 years," he asserted, "and which is kept in circulation still by people without religion and reason, although our school, which always contains from 80 to 100 children from 6 to 12 years of age and still contains such, contradicts this statement sufficiently." Although the relatively stable child population of New Harmony might have been explained in part by the influx of new families, orphans, and indentured servants, Frederick unwittingly prophesied the schism that later rent the Rappite membership when he added that "every reasonable person and one who knows human nature would easily see that a society of about 800 people could not live under a law of that kind and live in peace and unity for so many years." His explanation of this Utopian situation was that "the Harmony Society consists only of people who live the religion of Jesus practically and who pursue sanctification. Among these there are some of both sexes who have so advanced in sanctification and who by means of the power of the gospel of Jesus Christ and His vicarious atonement have been so ennobled in their virtue, that they of their own free will have given up carnal intercourse and devote themselves fully to prepare for Christ and His Kingdom, which kind of people have always existed and still exist, although their number has always been small."78

If not universally adhered to over a long period of time, celibacy nevertheless was a unifying factor in the Harmonist community immediately after its adoption. Only under peer pressure and Father Rapp's insistence on the chaste ideal did it become a divisive and destructive force within the group.79 Some members, especially among the younger generation, eventually found abstinence from sex an unreasonable expectation. A few of these dissenters withdrew from the Society from time to time, and about 175 left in a mass exodus from Economy, Pennsylvania , in 1832.80 Given the facts that the Harmonists never made any concerted effort to attract American members and that their celibate reputation often kept recent German immigrants from joining, they, in effect, staked the very survival of their beloved Harmony Society on the beginning of the millennium in their own lifetimes. Since this event did not occur, Rapp's community paid the customary toll for failure to produce sufficient offspring to perpetuate an organization
78 Arndt, Documentary History, I, 775.
79 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 358.
80 Ibid., 449–546.
and a faith. Extinction was the price of celibacy. The demise of the Harmony Society came in 1916, as the end had come eventually to other communitarians who had chosen this sexual discipline, notably the men of the Woman in the Wilderness commune near
Germantown, Pennsylvania , in the eighteenth century and later the Ephrata Cloister Baptists and all but about a dozen Shakers.81

Before this fate could overtake his Utopian dream, however, George Rapp and his associates weathered many other difficulties and wrote their accomplishments into American history. They moved from Harmony, Pennsylvania , to New Harmony in 1814 amid great expectations. Literally thousands of pietists were expected to join from Württemberg, and grape culture and river trade were to flourish. Father Rapp told his disciples that the move to the remote Indiana frontier would fulfill the passage in which the Sunwoman was "given two wings of a great eagle, that she might fly into the wilderness, into her place where she is nourished for a time, and times, and half a time, from the place of the serpent" (Rev. 12:14). After becoming established in New Harmony , the trusted leader announced that his Society as the Sunwoman would reach the zenith of her power after 1822 during the Era of the Golden Rose of Micah 4:8, and he directed that a rose be carved in the stone lintel above the door of the large cruciform church built in that year.82

However, the reasons for escaping into the wilderness and the early promise of the frontier location had already begun to disappear. Although several hundred joined the Society at New Harmony , German emigration fell far below Rapp's expectations. The Württemberg government had liberalized its treatment of religious dissenters, and Swedenborgian Johann Jung-Stilling had put forward a new biblical interpretaion which suggested that the prophetic flight of the Sunwoman would be to Russia, not to the United States . New Harmony 's climate, excellent for mosquitoes that caused malaria, was not favorable for vineyards. Its steaming summers proved debilitating to the people. The Wabash River was indeed serviceable for trade, but markets were far away, postal service uncertain,
81 Arndt, George Rapp's Successors and Material Heirs, 318–56; Mark Holloway, Heavens on Earth: Utopian Communities in America, 1680–1880 (rev. ed., New York , 1966), 37–43, 44–52; Richard L. Williams, "The Shakers, Now Only 12, Observe Their 200th Year," Smithsonian, V (September, 1974), 40–48.
82 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 143–63; Karl J. R. Arndt, "Luther's Golden Rose at New Harmony , Indiana," Concordia Historical Institute Quarterly, XLIX (Fall, 1976), 112–22.
frontier banks and currency unstable, and business tenuous at best. Even the frontier neighbors, except for the English-Americans at Albion, Illinois , proved less amiable than those of Pennsylvania who were more familiar with German culture.83

Resentment of nearby settlers seemed to focus more on the economic and political power of the Harmony Society, however, than on its cultural differences and religious sectarianism. In the early days at New Harmony George Rapp's life was threatened by frontiersmen who conspired to demand high wages for helping clear the land.84 As Rapp's town developed its monopoly on regional business, the high prices charged at the general store became a source of constant complaint.85 The Harmonists owned the only landing on the Wabash within miles and had intentionally purchased the strategically located Cut-Off Island just downstream; thus, the Society controlled shipping on the river. In 1818 twenty-one Posey County men brought these and other grievances to the attention of the Indiana General Assembly. Their petition asked that the indispensable New Harmony mill, at which they claimed grinding fees were exorbitant, be declared public property. When this plea was granted in 1820, Frederick Rapp protested, and the community interpreted the state coercion characteristically as persecution of the cause of Jesus.86 In the meantime, on January 20 and 21, 1820, local aggravation over economic and other matters had burst into physical attacks upon several Harmonists and a two-hour riot in the streets of the village.87

Since the Harmony Society could dominate local elections by voting with one mind, its strength was feared and its support often courted. As early as May, 1816, George Rapp was urged by a representative to the Indiana constitutional convention, Alexander Devin, to let his single vote represent all of the adult males of New Harmony . Otherwise, Devin predicted, the voters of the communal village would determine every election result, reap the wrath of the other county residents, and possibly endanger the enforcement of their own civil liberties.88 After the ballots from New Harmony were destroyed during one county election, the Rappites decided not to vote in
83 Arndt, Indiana Decade of George Rapp's Harmony Society, 15–16; Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 225, 292, 294.
84 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 157.
85 Ibid., 262; Arndt, Documentary History, I, 776.
86 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 261–65; Arndt, Documentary History, I, 78, 216–17, 440–43.
87 Arndt, Documentary History, II, 9–13.
88 Ibid., 216–17.
the next. Afterward they received a curious letter from one successful candidate thanking them for abstaining and inviting them to present their concerns for his attention.89

Ratliff Boon of Boonville successfully courted the Harmonist vote for state senator in 1818 and won. Later, in 1821, when he was lieutenent governor, he pleaded with George Rapp to deliver the Society vote to a Judge Thomas Givens for the Indiana Senate seat. "I am confident," wrote Boon, "that the present Election will depend Entirely on your votes, you have the power to Elect who you please, many of the people in the Country say, it is not worth their while to vote, for Harmonie can Elect Just who they please. …" Boon boldly requested that the Rappites either divide their votes equally Givens and his opponent, Elisha Harrison, or "be silent in the Election as to the senator" since "you have already a number of Enimies in consequence of your decided power to regulate Elections. …" The men of New Harmony , however, ignored Boon's advice and voted for Harrison; Givens lost.90

Despite the increasing political and economic prowess of his holy community, George Rapp became uneasy as the depression following 1819 worsened and his disciples grew restless awaiting the promised millennium. He sensed that if his authoritarian leadership and the vitality of his Harmony Society were to survive, another migration was necessary. But he knew it would not be easy to persuade his followers, who already had built two complete towns, to abandon the comforts of the second to erect yet a third. He tried to motivate them with the idea that a move back to Pennsylvania would be analogous to God's calling Abraham into a new land where his descendants would become a great nation through which the whole earth would be blessed.91 By March, 1824, when the decision to sell the beautiful town on the Wabash had been made, Father Rapp confided to Frederick that "this time it is not so accidental that we have such courage for the move."92 He later told Robert Owen, the wealthy manufacturer and social reformer of New Lanark, Scotland , who purchased New Harmony in 1825 for $150,000 to found his own secular communal experiment,
89 Arndt, Indiana Decade of George Rapp's Harmony Society, 19.
90 Arndt, Documentary History, II, 253–54, 266–67, 269–70. Judge Thomas Givens, having lost by only forty-eight votes to Harrison, contested the election results on the grounds that some of the Rappite men who voted had not yet been naturalized as citizens. Although this claim may have been correct, the Indiana Senate Committee on Elections confirmed the seating of Harrison. Ibid., 270; Indiana, Senate Journal (1821–1822), 17.
91 Genesis 12:1–2; Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 309.
92 Arndt, Documentary History, II, 812.
that it was sufficient to explain the Harmonist move by the fact that every ten years the Society simply looked for a new place to do some good.93

Economic advantage and religious utopianism, however, were apparently uppermost in the minds of the Rappite leaders. The location they chose for their last and most elaborate town was situated ideally for manufacturing and commerce a few miles down the Ohio River from Pittsburgh at present-day Ambridge. By calling their new settlement Economy, they indicated the basic direction of their thought. The name also fit well with George Rapp's latest vision of the "divine Economy" which he discussed in his Thoughts on the Destiny of Man, written during the weeks of reflection and relative inactivity just before leaving New Harmony .94 The divine Economy was the perfect world order of peace and plenty to be brought about by the communal endeavors of Christians united in brotherly love. Rapp maintained that his Harmony Society already had become the practical demonstration of the feasibility of this revolutionary development. In his words it was a "Noble Assylum! where brethren live together in unity and love, & form upon Earth, a Kingdom of God." Therefore, at Economy, Pennsylvania , the Society could be expected to "produce a heaven upon earth-A true HARMONY."95

The village of Economy fulfilled much of the economic promise of Rapp's vision but fell far short of the unity and love that were to bring about the Kingdom of God on earth. Ironically, Economy became the arena in which the Society's latent personality conflicts, power struggles, and millennial frustrations as well as Father Rapp's improprieties and errors in judgment surfaced and took their divisive toll. The Hildegard affair and the Count de Leon schism produced the turning points in the history of the community.

The aging, celibate Father Rapp permitted himself to become enamored with the beautiful, talented, and potentially seductive Hildegard Mutschler, who was born in the Harmony Society in 1806. She became his companion, confidante, and laboratory assistant in the late 1820s to the scandal of the other members and the disgust of Frederick. When she fell in love with Jacob Klein, the jealous Father Rapp unjustly cast him out of the fold, and a few other members withdrew in protest. Hildegard repeatedly betrayed her leader's confidence
93 Arndt, George Rapp's Harmony Society, 316.
94 Ibid., 308–10, 354, 589; Arndt, Documentary History, II, 812.
95 Rapp, Thoughts on the Destiny of Man, 63–66.
and lied to him about her illicit love affairs until she ran away from Economy with a young Society business agent, Conrad Feucht, in June, 1829. Instead of accepting her departure and recovering his self-control and the dignity of his office, Rapp discredited himself by publicly condemning his most faithful followers for prejudice against her and demanding that they pray for her return.

The Hildegard episode spread disillusion among the congregation, caused a few secessions, and broke the filial bond between Frederick and his father. In a deeply emotional, impeccably argued letter written at midnight on September 2, 1829, Frederick recounted the facts of the Hildegard affair for his father: the unreasonable conduct of the Harmonist leader, the great internal damage done to the membership, and the blight upon the community's reputation at large.96 Frederick had lost confidence in George Rapp. He could no longer be his alter ego. Frederick's early death at age fifty-nine in 1834 following the de Leon schism robbed the Harmony Society of one of its most faithful servants and was undoubtedly a product of these tragic events.97

After the Hildegard affair Father Rapp tried to recover the community's respect for his leadership. He worked feverishly but unsuccessfully in his laboratory to reaffirm his divine sanction by transforming base metal into gold. In the meantime a challenger arrived at Economy. Bernhard Mueller was a brash recent German immigrant who easily gained a following among Rapp's pietists by claiming to possess the philosopher's stone by which he alone could produce precious metal and by asserting to be the Count de Leon (the Lion of Judah) with divine right to supplant Rapp's millennial leadership. The competition that ensued between Rapp and Mueller made a mockery of their doctrines and a travesty of the name and purpose of the Harmony Society. In 1832 one third of the Society's members, about 175 in all, including the indispensable Christopher Mueller, left to follow the count's pseudoscience and flamboyant millennialism. Under the circumstances George and Frederick Rapp made a generous settlement of $105,000 with the departing members who organized the New Philadelphia Society and soon spent the money in two short-lived communal ventures at Phillipsburgh, Pennsylvania , and Grande Ecore, Louisiana .98

div.p: After the traumatic scandal and leadership crisis of the 1829–1832 period, the Harmony Society began an irreversible decline although its material wealth increased phenomenally. Father Rapp and his loyalists held ever more tenuously to their fading millennial hope. The community's dismay that their mentor could not make good his consistent promise to deliver it into Christ's presence was best said by the eighty-nine year old Rapp himself in his dying hour. "If I did not so fully believe that the Lord has designed me to place our society before his presence in the land of Canaan, I would consider this my last."99 Two decades after Rapp's death, which occurred on August 7, 1847, his aging Christian communists had been reduced to 146 in number; had shifted their economic emphasis from communal agriculture, manufacturing, and commerce to capitalistic investment in oil wells, pipelines, and railroads; and had begun to multiply their Society's wealth into the millions.100

The German immigrants who built New Harmony did not achieve perfection or realize their earthly Utopia, but their dream drove them across an ocean and sustained them for a century. Their Harmony Society became prominent in the American communal tradition. They contacted and influenced many of the other communal groups of the nineteenth century. Although George Rapp established but one communitarian society, he believed that small, voluntary associations of Christians working industriously under strong leaders would constitute the perfect world order of the future. Therefore, it was natural for his Society to emulate the Ephratans; to interact with the Shakers, Zoarites, Mormons, Keilites, Icarians, and Hutterites; to provide a communistic model and a ready-made town for the Owenites; and to help to inspire the founding of Brook Farm and Fruitlands.101
