div.p: The Harmony Society became one of the finest examples of the nine separate German-speaking communal groups which composed the largest distinctly ethnic element in this country's Utopian history, from the Woman in the Wilderness in 1694 to the Hutterite colonies of today. The Harmonists may have been more commercially aggressive, systematic in town planning, and, except for the Ephratans and the men of the Woman in the Wilderness, more intensely millennialistic and culturally active than the others. But their charismatic leadership, pietistic orientation, community of property, autocratic yet curiously democratic government, agricultural and manufacturing enterprises, divisive struggles for power, long life, and, with the exception of the Hutterites, eventual demise characterized all of the German-American communal societies.

The three towns built by the Harmonists exemplify the application of German material culture to the American environment. At Harmony, New Harmony , and Economy (Ambridge), Rappite churches, dwellings, granaries, vaulted wine cellars, gardens, cemeteries, tools, and handicarfts can be seen as enduring features of this German heritage. Original Harmonist half-log structures built of standardized, precut timbers marked by Roman numerals like those of Württemberg and utilizing pugging (boards daubed with mud and wrapped with straw for insulation and fire-proofing) have been preserved and restored.102 The importance of each Harmonist town has been recognized by its inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places.

The Harmonist story reveals much about the early American republic. It shows the difficulty involved in obtaining land grants from the federal government. It demonstrates the solidarity and economic potential of corporate bodies conducting business in a free enterprise system. Like the developing national economy, that of the Harmony Society moved from agriculture to manufacturing and the beginnings of investment capitalism in oil and railroading. The Harmonist experience illustrates the extent of American religious toleration to pacifists in Pennsylvania during and following the War of 1812 and in Indiana during the writing of the first Constitution and thereafter.103 The record also shows marks made by the Harmonists
102 Donald E. Pitzer, "The Harmonist Heritage of Three Towns," Historic Preservation, XXIX (October-December, 1977), 5–10; Ralph G. Schwartz, "Action for the Public Interest: An Environmental Approach to Historic Preservation," Lake Forest Academy Antique Show, 1977 (Lake Forest, Ill., 1977), 24–31; Charles M. Stotz, "Threshold of the Golden Kingdom: The Village of Economy and Its Restoration," in Ian M. G. Quimby, ed., Winterthur Portfolio 8 (Winterthur, Del., 1973), 133–69; Larner, "‘Nails and Sundrie Medicines,’" 134–36.
103 Arndt, Documentary History, I, 116, 125, 143, 144, 183, 184, 609, 634–36, 657, 658, 698–700, II, 84, 85, 100, 159, 331, 340.
upon the nation. Their well-preserved German ways were a cultural yeast in Pennsylvania and Indiana and as far away as the Gulf of Mexico and the Pacific coast as their schismatics moved across the nation. The strong beer, whiskey, wine, and excellent flannel and woolen cloth that issued from Rappite breweries, distilleries, and mills were enjoyed by uncounted Americans. And throughout its existence the Harmony Society provided a conspicuous alternative by which the general society could test the validity of its own institutions.

Not the least of the Rappite achievements had occurred during their New Harmony decade. The Harmonists helped open the West. Their twenty-thousand-acre communal estate with its remarkable town, mills, and workshops contributed to the economic development of Indiana. Their counsel and talent aided in the formation of the state and the selection of the site and quite possibly the design for the permanent capital at Indianapolis . They provided loans to the fledgling state. They played a significant part in local politics, usually contributing in proportion to their influence.104 Their music, school, library, and publications raised the cultural level of the region. Their carefully planned village was a blueprint for other communities, especially the English Prairie settlement at Albion, Illinois , after 1817.105

George Rapp could look back with great satisfaction on all these accomplishments on the afternoon of May 24, 1824, as he sailed away to continue his Utopian adventure with the first contingent of the seven hundred Harmonists moving to Economy. George Schaal, one of the faithful on the boat with him, had written their benediction on the staircase in Dormitory Number 2: "On the twenty-fourth of May, 1824, we have departed. Lord, with Thy great help and goodness, in body and soul protect us." With one last salute from the town cannon that had been used so carelessly the year before to celebrate the arrival of the first steamboat, Father Rapp and his party moved slowly out of sight down the Wabash and were gone.106

div.p: GEORGE RAPP

In May, 1826, Duke Bernhard of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach visited Economy, Pennsylvania —having been to New Harmony , Indiana, the previous month—and described George Rapp, founder and spiritual leader of the Harmony Society:
The elder Rapp is a large man, seventy years old, whose powers age seems not in the least to have diminished; his hair is gray, but his blue eyes overshadowed by strong brows, are full of life and fire; his voice is strong, and full of expression; by his strange gestures he knows how to give a special emphasis to that which he says. He speaks a Swabian dialect, intermixed with a little English.1

The two existing portraits of Rapp are both questioned by scholars. The picture opposite is painted on wood and identified by Christiana Knoedler in her memoirs of life in the Harmony Society.2 Tradition says that Rapp went to Warsaw, New York , in 1830 in search of merino sheep. He found what he wanted at the farm of a Major General Staunton, a veteran of the War of 1812. Staunton and his son Pheneas accompanied Rapp back to Economy and purchased Holland sheep for themselves. Pheneas painted Rapp's picture en route. The general's granddaughter, Emily A. Peck, sold it to the Society in 1894. In the Harmonie Herald, April, 1970, however, Daniel B Reibel states that the portrait was done by an apprentice cattle drover who became an artist.3
The copperplate print of Rapp, below, serves as the frontispiece for Ernst Ludwig Brauns' Amerika und die moderne Bölkerwanderung (Potsdam, 1833).

div.p: WEINGARTNER MAP

Map of New Harmony , Indiana, drawn from memory by Wallrath Weingartner in 1832, seven or eight years after the Harmony Society had returned to Pennsylvania . Though other contemporaneous maps exist, it is the only one which depicts the physical appearance of the buildings in 1824. The photograph above is of the original map with several impaired sections restored.
HARMONIST HOUSE CONSTRUCTION

The development of house construction in New Harmony reflects the limitations of building equipment, materials, and manpower. Two distinct phases are evident in the building and growth of the town. Generally speaking, between 1814 and 1819, most of the structures were of log. They were built principally with squared timbers but sometimes of round unhewn logs, mainly poplar or oak. The corners were cut and shaped to interlock with reverse angles, thus preventing their pulling apart. The space between the logs was chinked with small wood shims and a clay grouting mixed with straw and river shells. Roofs were framed with rafters and mortised and tenoned at the peak. Walls were erected initially with no openings. Windows were cut when glass and sash became available. Some chimneys were built for fireplaces; however, most were constructed for stoves that were used for heating and food preparation, though not baking, as there were community bake ovens on each block. To control vermin, interiors of the later log houses were whitewashed and floors scrubbed with sand, lye, and hot water.

The early dwellings were placed back from the street, leaving room for more permanent construction later. The advent of a sawmill and brick kiln made this possible. Between 1819 and 1824, when phase two of the building development took place, houses were either of frame or brick, dimensions of the latter typically 22′6″ by 30′6″ and the former 20′3″ by 28′3″. Framing elements were numbered with Roman numerals (a device frequently used in German construction), allowing for quick and accurate assembling.

Though there were minor variations in all buildings, these houses had certain common characteristics. They had six rooms: a stair hall, kitchen, and common room on the first floor; a stair hall and two bedrooms on the second. All rooms were entered from the halls and none interconnected. There was a single entrance from a side yard rather than from the street. Each house had ten windows placed high to insure privacy and two small gable windows at each end of the attic. Interior walls were plastered and trimmed with simple beaded boards, as were the clapboard exteriors.
Each house had a barn which accommodated equipment and a cow and incorporated the outhouse.4

ST. STEPHEN'S RECTORY
Restored Episcopalian church rectory illustrating features of Harmonist frame construction: unpainted poplar weather- boarding, beading for decoration, windows with sashes containing six panes each.

The Harmonists used the pugging method to provide insulation and fire-proofing in construction. So-called "Dutch biscuits" were made by wrapping tapered slats of wood with straw and mud and then inserting them between the floor joists and wall studs which contained grooves. Generally the "biscuits" measured about eighteen inches long and seven inches wide. They effectively kept the winter heat in, the summer heat out, and sound in its proper place. Picture above shows exposed lathing and plaster in one of the Harmonist houses.
SOLOMON WOLF

Solomon Wolf came to the United States with the Harmony Society in August, 1805, and was listed in the log of the ship "Margaret" as a farmer. During the New Harmony period, however, he was a shepherd and lived, according to the Weingartner map, adjacent to the sheep barns. In an August 14, 1817, letter, William Smith, writing to Frederick Rapp in Pittsburgh, said: "Solomon Wolf and Peter Schreiber have been sent to Kentucky to buy sheep, but they returned a few days ago and brought along 45 head, the average price with costs runs to $2.55 each."5

Built in 1823, Wolfs house was located at the present site of the Tree of Life Clinic on the north side of South Street between Main and Brewery streets, until May, 1975, when it was moved to the location of a comparable brick house belonging to Christian Eigner on the southeast corner of Brewery and Granary streets. Its removal offered an opportunity for archaeological investigation never before possible. div.p: HARMONIST SCHOOLHOUSE

The Harmonist schoolhouse was once located in the present yard of Murphy Auditorium. Dr. Johann Christoph Mueller, the society's doctor, schoolmaster, and musical composer, conducted school in the northeast portion of the first floor. This building also housed the press on which were printed the first Harmony Society books shortly before the Rappites removed to Economy.

In 1825 the New Harmony
Gazette, official organ of the Robert Owen Community, was published in the former school room on a new Super-Royal press. The printers, Thomas B. Palmer and Robert Jennings, occupied the premises during their tenure.

When the house was torn down in 1913, the newspaper account recorded: "Yellow poplar entered largely into its makeup and some of the timbers are huge. One beam runs clear across the house and is 47 feet long, 12 x 18 inches. Many of the joists and rafters are hewed poplar and three times as large as the present day pieces." In addition, some bricks were found with the date 1822 and various inscriptions—one with the name of Samuel Bradford Birkbeck (son of Morris).6 The small picture below is from Wallrath Weingartner's "Map of New Harmony on the Wabash , 1814–1825," showing the Harmonist schoolhouse. div.p: GEORGE RAPP'S HOUSE

George Rapp's house was built several years (ca. 1817-1818) after the arrival of the Harmonists. Whenever mentioned by visitors, the house was described as a large handsome building and was compared in size to No. 2 Community House (after 1821) across the way. Elias Pym Fordham in his Personal Narrative of Travels …, 1817–1818 called it "by far the best in Indiana." In an inventory of buildings and real estate dated January 16, 1819, "Mr. Rapp's brick house" is valued at $3,500.7 The picture below is a photograph of a model of New Harmony as it is thought to have appeared in 1824. The Rapp mansion is in the foreground. The detail is from Wallrath Weingartner's "Map of New Harmony on the Wabash , 1814–1825," showing George Rapp's house.

div.p: FOOTPRINT ROCK

The limestone slab lying in the yard of the Rapp mansion was purchased by Frederick Rapp in St. Louis in 1819. The two footprints are Indian petroglyphs carved by the aborigines in the St. Louis area. A letter written to Romelius L. Baker of Economy by Paul Anderson, October 12, 1841, describing the quarrying and acquisition of the stone, was intended for and used by David Dale Owen in an article, "Regarding Human Foot-prints in Solid Limestone." In explaining the rock's geological history, Owen astutely observed: "It appears to me much less improbable that some aboriginal artist should have exhibited unlocked for skill in intagliating a rock than that a man should have been coeval with Crustacea."8 Local tradition refers to the slab as Gabriel's Rock, thus alluding to a tale supposedly told by Father Rapp to his followers to the effect that the Angel had thus imprinted the slab on his heavenly descent to assist him in the Society's affairs.

list.item: 8 David Dale Owen, "Regarding Human Foot-prints in Solid Limestone," American Journal of Science and Arts, XLIII (October, 1842), 14–32.

div.p: FRAME CHURCH

Only one contemporary sketch of a Harmonist building still exists—Adlard Welby's sketch of the white frame church done in 1821 (A Visit to North America and the English Settlements in Illinois
, 1821). A Mr. Courtney who had visited New Harmony two years before—in 1819—described it thus: "A large substantial brick [sic] church, with its steeple, clock and bell, is of course the most conspicuous building: it has three floors; but the lower one only is used for public worship: the second, equally good and well lighted, and probably designed for some public purpose, is not at present much used: the upper one is merely a very spacious loft of considerable height, under the ridge of the large roof."9

The bell mentioned by various travelers with pleasure had been ordered by Frederick Rapp, September 9, 1817, from William Barber and Co., Liverpool, England . Frederick wrote: "a Bell to weigh between 15 and 16 Cwt. from one of the Founderies in England . It is intended for a religious Society of Germany , who have settled themselves on the Wabash River, Indiana State, in a place called Harmony. It possesses about 25,000 Acres of Land in one Tract and the Bell is chiefly intended to notify particular Hours of the Day to the Members who may be occupied in different, and at times distant parts of the Settlement. The Sound should therefore not only be solemn, but loud." 10

The bell was shipped by way of New Orleans and arrived in April or May of 1819 in time to be mentioned by Mr. Courtney. At a cost of 153 pounds, 7 shillings, 1 pence, and import duty of about 20 percent Frederick got the loud bell he wanted; for it is said that the sound carried into the surrounding woods for seven miles distant.

The Harmonists' manner of worship was described in some detail by Elias Pym Fordham on May 6, 1818, in his travel journal: "The men sit at one end of the church and the women at the other; and Mr. Rapp sits while he preaches in a chair placed on a stage, about one yard high, with a table before him. When I heard him one week day evening, he wore a linsey woolsey coat and a blue worsted night cap. In praying the Harmonists do not rise up or kneel down, but bend their bodies forward, almost to their knees."11

div.p: THE GRANARY

Though now just three stories high, the granary originally had five stories until a fire in 1878 destroyed the upper floors and the tile-covered hip roof. During the Harmonist occupation it was used mainly for grain storage. Three large, strong, thick doors, furnished with enormous locks—one measuring 151/2 inches by 81/2 inches, with a key approximately 10 inches long—helped to secure the contents of the building.

In 1843 the granary became the third laboratory and museum of David Dale Owen and was the headquarters for the geological surveys commissioned by the federal government. Later it was used for numerous purposes, including a woolen mill, a flour mill, and a pork-packing plant.12 The picture below is a portion of David Dale Owen's sketch of Church Street looking east from the West Street intersection and showing the Granary.

div.p: DORMITORY No. 2

Completed in 1822, the No. 2 Bruder Haus, which accommodated single men and women, was one of the major communal buildings of the Harmony Society (and later of the Owen Community when it served many functions, including a Pestalozzian school and print shop). According to several accounts, all the larger brick dwellings had a gallery running through the center with rooms on either side opening one into the other.13 The photograph below is of a model of New Harmony as it is thought to have appeared in 1824. Dormitory No. 2 and the kitchen along side it are in the foreground. Detail is from Wallrath Weingartner's "Map of New Harmony on the Wabash , 1814–1825," showing Dormitory No. 2.

div.p: SUN DIAL

Until the early 1960s Dormitory No. 2 displayed on its southern facade a sun dial dated 1821. Made of oak boards with a strategically placed iron rod for casting shadows to number the hours, the sun dial had been originally placed by the Harmonists on Father Rapp's house and served as the town clock. When the mansion burned in 1844, the sun dial was put on No. 2 until an extensive state restoration program caused it to be brought inside the building where it now rests.14

div.p: DORMITORY No. 4: THE OPERA HOUSE

Dormitory No. 4 was one of the last (1823–1824) of the large community buildings constructed by the Harmonists. Like No. 2 it housed unmarried members of the Harmony Society. During the Owen Community it also served as living quarters, and at one time its sixteen large rooms accommodated sixteen families. Its greatest distinction, however, lies in the long and distinguished role it played in New Harmony theatrical history from 1856 to 1913. The present façade was added in 1888 by Eugene S. Thrall. The Opera House was restored in 1969. The picture below is of old No. 4 as it appeared in the 1870s, when it was called Union Hall and before the façade was added. On the following page is the Opera House as it appears today.
BRICK CHURCH GEMEINDE HAUS

Begun in 1822, the impressive brick church of the Harmonists was still not quite complete in December of 1824 when Robert Owen arrived with the view of purchasing the Harmonist village. Both Owen's son William and Donald Macdonald recorded that fact in their diaries. The English traveler, William Hebert, who visited the society while the building was under construction, was impressed with its "nobility" and "grandeur" and wrote an excellent description of its appearance:
These people exhibit considerable taste as well as boldness of design in some of their works. They are erecting a noble church, the roof of which is supported in the interior by a great number of stately columns, which have been turned from trees of their own forests. The kinds of wood made use of for this purpose are, I am informed, black walnut, cherry, and sassafras. Nothing I think can exceed the grandeur of the joinery, and the masonry and brick-work seem to be of the first order. The form of this church is that of a cross, the limbs being short and equal; and as the doors, of which there are four, are placed at the ends of the limbs, the interiour of the building as seen from the entrance, has a most ample and spacious effect. A quadrangular story or compartment containing several rooms, is raised on the body of the church, the sides of which inclining inwards towards the top, are terminated by a square gallery, in the centre of which is a small circular tower of about ten feet in height, which is surmounted with a silvered globe. The reason assigned by our guide for the erection of this fine edifice was, that the first church being built wholly of wood, is found to be so hot during the summer, when the whole of the society are assembled within it, as to be scarcely supportable, in consequence of which it was resolved to delay the building of their houses for a time, and raise a more spacious and substantial place of worship, and the one they are employed upon bids fairly to do them honor, both in the design and execution. It is much more spacious than the number of their society requires. I could scarcely imagine myself to be in the woods of Indiana, on the borders of the Wabash , while pacing the long resounding aisles, and surveying the stately colonades of this church. Here too the Englishman is once more gratified with the sound of a church bell, which however harsh it may sometimes be thought by those who have never strayed beyond the sound of one, imparts a gratification after a period of estrangement from it, as connected with early associations, infinitely more soothing than could the most delicate strains of music.15

NORTH DOOR OF BRICK CHURCH: "DOOR OF PROMISE"

The north door of the brick church with its stone lintel designed and executed by Frederick Rapp has had an interesting history. When the church was taken down in 1874, it became the north door of the public school built on the same site. When this early school was replaced by the present school building in 1913, the door was moved to the west where it is situated today.

The Golden Rose symbol has its identification in the German Lutheran version of Bible verse Micah 4:8: "And thou Tower of Eden, the stronghold of the daughter of Zion, the golden rose shall come, the former dominion, the Kingdom of the daughter of Jerusalem."16 Below are the plans for the Door of Promise as drawn by Frederick Rapp.

figure.p: Over two hundred Harmonists died at New Harmony , Indiana, and were buried in unmarked graves. There is, however, a list—written in German by Romelius L. Baker—which names the persons buried in the cemetery.

In the enclosure there are also several Indian mounds (of the Hopewell prehistoric culture) which were investigated by some of the Owen-period naturalists, notably Charles Alexandre Lesueur, as well as some members of the Harmony Society before him.

div.p: HARMONIST COFFIN

Burial customs in the Harmony Society were simple. True to the Harmonists' stress on equality in death as in life, no marker was placed on the graves. And because the Harmonists felt that the life to come was all-important, death in this one meant only the cessation of work and sorrow, with quiet sleep in the orchard burial ground until called up for the Second Coming.

In a brief ceremony the black hexagonal coffin, accompanied by a small number of mourners consisting of family, intimate friends, and the elders, was brought to the grave. A few prayers and hymns, some remarks, small bouquets of flowers placed in the grave—and "another brother had gone home."17 The coffin above, on view in the New Harmony Workingmen's Institute Museum, is five feet, one inch long.

div.p: THE LABYRINTH

The Harmonists built labyrinths in all three of their towns. In mystic fashion they represented Father Rapp's idea that one has to tread the tortuous way of life before attaining the rewards of Heaven.

A number of the visitors to New Harmony mentioned the "pleasure garden," but the best descriptions remain in the recollections of the children who grew up in the Owenite community. Victor Duclos, who came to New Harmony in 1826 as a child of eight, remembered the labyrinth thus: "Within a circle of about 140 feet in diameter there were formed concentric circles with growth of hedge plants, presenting an intricate pathway leading to a small block house in the centre. The house was built of blocks of wood about twelve inches long pointed at one end. These were placed with the pointed ends outward to form a circular wall."18

Miner K. Kellogg, portrait artist, spent his eleventh and twelfth years as a participant in the Owen Community (1825-1827). Sixty years after, he wrote:
The first Labyrinth I ever saw was at New Harmony . It was grown in an open field near the town and a source of constant amusement to children. Its lines were formed of vines grown upon light fences and about four feet high, converging as they reached the centre. Here the visitor came upon a circular hut made of the ends of rough logs cut to a point externally leaving one window—& a blind door which had to be sought out—& only found by pushing at the walls. I remember well my first visit to this hut, after a long & tedious run back and forth through the labyrinth. On seeking for the door a large snake took a look at me from between the logs, laughing at me with its long red tongue. I got back out of the labyrinth much sooner and easier than I found my way in.19

div.p: MUSIC AND MANUSCRIPT BOOKS

Music played a major role in the life of the Harmonists. Since the opportunity to study music was available to anyone who wished, many did so, to the extent that the making of, or listening to, music was their most popular pastime and formed an intrinsic part of their daily social and religious affairs. According to Richard Wetzel, the Harmony Society period on the Wabash "was one of intensive and methodical music study and the proficiency of the orchestra in the late 1820s was the result of the teaching effort expended during this time."20

Musically, 1817 was a banner year in New Harmony with the arrival of some special musical instruments. The Rosenbaum "piano forty" weighing 379 pounds, obtained from Abishai Way, and a special purchase from Allyn Bacon Company containing, among other things, a pair of horns, cost $30.00; a pair of bassoons, $30.00; and two octave flutes, $4.00, augmented the quality of the Harmonists' orchestra and teaching opportunities. Inspired, perhaps, by the new instruments, Father Rapp was reported in August to have "given out [a song] for singing in the private devotion next Sunday."21

A list of Christmas music performed at New Harmony in 1817 combines vocal and instrumental pieces. One piece for voice and flute, "O Nacht, und du O feyerliche Stille," was composed by the Society's innkeeper, Frederick Eckensperger.22

In addition to George Rapp, Frederick Rapp and John Christopher Mueller were the main composers of hymns for the Harmonists. Often the words, or poems, were original and set to popular German folk sources, although both Mueller and Frederick sometimes composed their own music as well as the words.

Concerts by the " Wabash Orchestra" and oratorio or cantata performances by smaller groups for persons other than Society members were noticed and praised by the press. A list of the singers and instrumentalists reveals well-known Harmonist names: Dr. John Christopher Mueller, Gertrude Rapp, Jonathan Lentz, Wallrath Weingartner, Jacob Henrici, Hil-degarde Mutschler, Conrad Feucht, and others.23

div.p: Various travelers duly noted the social role music played in the Harmony Society. Young William Owen, who lived in New Harmony during the final months of Harmonist occupation, mentioned numerous occasions when he and Captain Donald MacDonald attended social functions at which music was sung and played and in which he joined.24

Time was not only spent in performing, however; an equal amount of attention and effort was put into the copying of music and other subjects as well. Many manuscript books now in the archives at Economy, Pennsylvania , but produced in Indiana, attest to the progressive educational practices of the Society. Both individuals and groups were encouraged to express their ideas in creative forms such as hymns, songs, and poems or to copy the works of well-known literary personnages like Friedrich von Schiller and Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. The familiar names also appear on these manuscript books, which bear the dates they were begun and the names, and sometimes birth dates, of the persons who compiled them. Frequently the title page was artistically done in fraktur with floral ornamentation and the whole bound in leather. Subjects other than hymns are recorded: penmanship and grammar exercises, arithmetic problems, and even, as in the case of Wallrath Weingartner's books, directions for making dyes.25 Below is a photograph of a hymn sung at Father Rapp's funeral.

div.p: WALLRATH WEINGARTNER

Wallrath Weingartner, whose name appears regularly in the cultural manuscripts of the Harmony Society, was born in Gross Glattbach , District of Moulbronn, Württemberg, Germany , May 4, 1795. He was the son of Frederick and Christina Weingartner who emigrated with their family to the United States , arriving February 16, 1805.

In addition to the very important maps of the two Harmonies, Weingartner's most interesting work is the manuscript he entitled "Ornithology or the Natural History of the Birds of the United States . Illustrated with Plats [sic]. Economy. 15 January. 1829," into which he copied with skill and artistry over sixty birds from Alexander Wilson's Ornithology. 27 Several of the illustrations on the following page allow for a comparison of the original Wilson plate with the Weingartner rendering. The copyist did not always reproduce exactly what he saw in Wilson's work but often picked examples from various plates, regrouped them, and created new arrangements. Weingartner's text is an abstract or resume of the Wilson essays that accompanied each of the bird drawings.

div.p: MILLS AND MANUFACTURES

After a few months in the Harmony Society's new home on the Wabash , George Rapp wrote a letter to Frederick, who was still in Pennsylvania , telling of the general state of things in New Harmony , illness and death among the members, and their needs. He also described the countryside and the lay of the land and his plans for its development:
I have searched through the entire land and found many advantages which it has; e.g., I shall lead a little brook, which takes a left course about a quarter mile above the town now right through the middle street down the valley to the bank for general use, except the grinding mill. This will give me 14 to 15 foot fall, so the water can turn a mill half a year and often longer only 100 steps from the lower street of the town, and the brick maker, the tanner, and whoever else needs water for his trade can live along the stream. Then Gressing's creek has a beautiful stream of water, 9 to 10 acres [?]. On that place the sawmill should be built, and from there the water should be led into the town so that in the upper street toward morning it will run toward midnight toward the bank and have a fall of 14 to 15 feet. The spring in Gray's land has a fall of about 5 feet down to the town and 3 quarter mile distant, and is so strong that it will drive a mill wheel the entire year without the springs and little creeks which in the vicinity of the town run out of the hills, and which can be used and still have quite a bit of water during this dry season, but they disappear underground because they have no decent bed on which to move. Furthermore, the mill site in the cutoff is the most beautiful and best mill site within a distance of 100 miles. The entire bed for a length of 2 miles is a pavement of rock and no broader than your creek, and there is never a lack of water. Then by the town along the outer street toward south there is a small pond which has running water throughout the year.28
Basic products generated by the Harmonist industrial system for their subsistence and sale included textiles, flour, lumber, alcoholic beverages, leather, rope, ceramics, cured meats, and oils.

The Harmonist grist mill was located two miles south of New Harmony on the east bank of the Cut-off River. The picture on the following page shows it as sketched by Charles Alexandre Lesueur; it was recalled by Victor Duclos as a three-story frame building, "run by water power, containing four run of stones." In a March 28, 1816, report on New Harmony , Frederick Rapp wrote back to Pennsylvania : "our Steam Engine will also come in Opperation in the course of 3 or 4 weeks, we shall run 2 pr. mill stones with it besides our machineries, till we get time to build a large mill with at least 4 or 6 pr. Sts. for which we have an exellent Seat 2 miles from the town, and is convinient to Ship every thing by water to and from it."29

HARMONIST POTTERY

Samples of Harmonist pottery, opposite page, found during an archaeological excavation of the foundations of the Solomon Wolf house. The plate is decorated with the characteristic Harmonist painted yellow zig-zag design. Both specimens are salt-glazed and brown in color.
AN EXAMPLE OF HARMONIST SILK

Although the Harmonists did not establish at New Harmony what later became one of their most famous manufactures, they were already thinking and planning their silk industry while still in Indiana. As their original planting of Lombardy poplar trees died, they began replacing them with mulberries, an indication of future plans for the propagation of silkworms.

At Economy, as early as 1826, the Society began the development of silk manufacture under the able direction of Gertrude Rapp. Very precise and detailed records were kept of this industry to the extent that today the Society's archives represent an invaluable resource of information about American sericulture.31

div.p: No. 2 STAIRWAY INSCRIPTION

In 1824 the Harmonists left their unique town on the Wabash to begin anew in Pennsylvania . Written in chalk under one of the stairways in Dormitory No. 2 is a touching inscription placed there hastily by a departing Harmonist: "On the twenty-fourth of May, 1824, we have departed. Lord, with Thy great help and goodness, in body and soul protect us."
